comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: On the 1890 map of Sydney (John Sands) the bay now known as Clovelly is called "LIT. COOGEE BAY". Not near Coogee as we know it today. See: www.nla.gov.au/apps/cdview?pi=nla.map-rm1280-s1-sd&rg... Btw the map also refers to Tamarama as 'DIXONS BAY', Bronte as 'NELSON BAY' , and the point south of Coogee as 'South Bondi'. All very confusing for a time-travelling taxi (or Hansom cab) driver! I am tempted to add the tags "nude, naked, swim, boy, man" and watch the views increase tenfold. Quality not quantity!

comment.author: 34205733@N05
comment._content:
that has to be a print error, marking South Coogee headland as South Bondi. I grew up around Coogee Beach and often walked to Gordon's bay (which was also known locally in the 60's as 'Shark Bay') and then around to Clovelly ,which in the 60's was already known as Clovelly Beach. I had never heard Clovelly Beach referred to as Little Coogee. 
I learn something every day from these old photos and maps.

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: "South Bondi" must be right; it also appears on the 1875 map - www.nla.gov.au/apps/cdview?pi=nla.map-f110-sd&rgn=0.7... , and in 1903 - www.nla.gov.au/apps/cdview?pi=nla.map-rm1635-sd&rgn=0... Changing place and street names are without rhyme or reason! Elizabeth and Castlereagh Streets used to start at Circular Quay; all delightfully confusing. I had incorrectly always thought Bronte was named after the sisters, but Lord "Nelson was created Duke of Bronte by the King of Naples in July 1799, and after briefly experimenting with the signature "Brontë Nelson of the Nile" signed himself "Nelson & Brontë" for the rest of his life." Ref - en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Horatio_Nelson,_1st_Viscount_Nelson... The 1875 map show several streets in honour of Nelson, eg Nelson Road, Nelson Bay Road, Trafalgar Road, Frenchmans Road, Victory St, Albion St., etc.- www.nla.gov.au/apps/cdview?pi=nla.map-f110-sd&rgn=0.7...

comment.author: 22929657@N00
comment._content: I wonder if the "K & Co" is Kable & Co. FW Kable was a semi-professional photographer around that time.

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: @ Murfomurf - "K & Co." is Sydney firm Charles Kerry & Co.  See details at Persistent URL link above, and zoom right in for incredible detail as on all these Powerhouse Museum photos.

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content:
An interesting letter (from the SMH 14/9/1939 p.5) about learning to swim here in 1884 and how it was the only Sydney beach where surf swimming was "freely indulged in" before the laws were changed in 1904 - trove.nla.gov.au/ndp/del/article/17630802 .
I TO THE EDITOR OF THE HERALD. I Sir,-My knowledge of Clovelly Beach goes back to 1884, when, as a child of seven, I learnt to swim there, and even then it was at week-ends frequented by crowds of swimmers. As the years went by this popularity ceased and it was for many years prior to 1904 the only Sydney beach where open sea bathing was freely indulged in, and though at rare intervals a policeman from Randwick would visit the beach, the authorities very seldom enforced the law against bathing. Though Little Coogee is sheltered from the north and the surf does not beat there to the extent it does on the other beaches, it is surf bathing nevertheless and Little Coogee can well claim the honour of being the first Sydney beach where surf bathing as we know it to-day started. Yours etc R H REID Tamworth Sept 12 [1939]
